content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved the puzzle in Python, fairly simple to implement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Answered in C++.
The statement is simple, easy, and great for beginners.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's very simple, maybe even too simple. For a beginner, however, it does at least show where floats and doubles can matter. It also gets one to output a number to a specific number of decimal places including if the decimal places are zero.

Completed in c++.

Goal
* Please change "is is" to "is".

* Please format all instances of "m1", "m2" and "r" as [[variables]].

* Please format all instances of "G" as a {{constant}}.

Input
* Please change "m_1" and "m_2" to "m1" and "m2" for consistency.

* Please add a description to every variable, e.g. add "for the mass of the first object" after "[[m1]]".

Output
* Please format "G" as a {{constant}}.

* Please delete the example.

Constraints
* Please change "m_1" and "m_2" to "m1" and "m2" for consistency.

* Please change 10^20 to 10^10 which is closer to the maximum values covered in the cases.

Cases
* Please revise "Bigger" (test) so that rounding is required (i.e. the output doesn't contain ".00").

* Please revise "BIG BOY" (test) and "Validator 3" so that (1) rounding is required, and (2) all intermediate and final calculation results (including m1 * m2) won't exceed 2^64. The reason is that not all programming languages available on CG are able to handle very large numbers.

Thanks.

I put all the m1 and m2 as m_1 and m_2, for the system does not allow letters next to numbers
Thanks for the information!
Which section are you talking about? The stub generator?

Goal
* Please format the unformatted instances of "m_1", "m_2" and "r" as [[variables]].

* Please format the two unformatted instances of "G" as a {{constant}}.

Constraints
* Please change "10^10" to "10^7" as the cases were changed.

Thanks.
